Graphical abstract This review succinctly outlines the key challenges encountered with Zn metal anodes and thoroughly examines electrolyte additive engineering, elucidating the mechanisms through which various additives impact Zn-based aqueous batteries. Zn-based aqueous batteries (ZABs) are gaining widespread popularity due to their low cost and high safety profile. However, the application of ZABs faces significant challenges, such as dendrite growth and parasitic reactions of metallic Zn anodes. Therefore, achieving high-energy–density ZABs necessitates addressing the fundamental thermodynamics and kinetics of Zn anodes. Various strategies are available to mitigate these challenges, with electrolyte additive engineering emerging as one of the most efficient and promising approaches. Despite considerable research in this field, a comprehensive understanding of the intrinsic mechanisms behind the high performance of electrolyte additives remains limited. This review aims to provide a detailed introduction to functional electrolyte additives and thoroughly explore their underlying mechanisms. Additionally, it discusses potential directions and perspectives in additive engineering for ZABs, offering insights into future development and guidelines for achieving high-performance ZABs. Keywords Aqueous batteries Zn anodes Electrolyte additive engineering Interfacial chemistry Electrochemical mechanisms 1 Introduction To achieve carbon neutrality by the middle of the 21st century, efficient renewable and clean energy storage has become a top research priority in the global energy sector. Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) have revolutionized the energy market and impacted people's lives due to their high energy density and long cycle life [1–4]. However, the use of organic media in LIBs, which contributes to their high energy density, has raised safety concerns, exemplified by incidents like electric vehicle combustion [5–8]. Additionally, the limited availability and high cost of lithium resources have hindered further the development and widespread adoption of LIBs [9–11]. Therefore, there is an urgent need to develop a new energy storage technology that is environmentally friendly, safe, and cost-effective [12–14]. Among the potential alternatives, Zn-based aqueous batteries (ZABs) have attracted significant attention as a new generation of rechargeable batteries due to their impressive theoretical capacity (820 mAh g−1 or 5855 mAh cm−3), lower cost (approximately 20–30 percent less than the price of Li), moderate redox potential (–0.76 V vs. standard hydrogen electrode (SHE)), and abundance (about 300 times more abundant than Li) [15–17]. Based on the above advantages, ZABs have promising prospects in electric vehicles, portable electronic devices, flexible and wearable devices, and large-scale energy storage systems. The concept of ZABs was first proposed in 2012, revealing the reaction mechanism of Zn2+ embedded in MnO2 in a mild ZnSO4 or Zn(NO3)2 aqueous electrolyte [18]. However, the practical application of ZABs faces several challenges, including uncontrolled dendrite growth during Zn plating/stripping, hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), corrosion, and passivation [19,20], all of which detrimental affect redox kinetics and Coulombic efficiency (CE) [21,22], ultimately accelerating the degradation of the metallic Zn anode [23,24]. Therefore, there is an urgent need to optimize nucleation, induce homogeneous Zn plating/stripping, and suppress parasitic reactions. To address these challenges, researchers have invested significant efforts in exploring various strategies, including interfacial modulation, structural regulation, separator design, and electrolyte optimization. Interfacial modulation aims to enhance the electrode/electrolyte interface and zincophilicity kinetics, promoting the uniform distribution of electric and ionic fields to facilitate Zn deposition [25,26]. However, its effectiveness is limited to the surface of the Zn anode and fails to suppress crack formation during long-term cycling, especially at high current densities. This limitation arises from the significant volume variation of the Zn metal anode, which compromises the protective function of the interface. In contrast, three-dimensional (3D) electrode design helps alleviate the limitation of electrode reaction kinetics imposed by commercial Zn foil to some extent, thereby enhancing the electrochemical performance of the battery under high current density [27,28]. Nonetheless, the uneven growth of Zn metal poses challenges in regulating it within the internal space of 3D structured electrodes. As a critical interface between the electrode and electrolyte, a well-designed separator enables uniform ion flux, prevents dendrite formation, and inhibits the shuttling of dissolved ions [29,30]. However, the high cost and poor mechanical properties of the currently reported separators for ZABs severely limit their large-scale application. Electrolyte optimization, encompassing hydrogel electrolytes, eutectic electrolytes and additive engineering, emerges as a practical method to enhance the Zn anode stability compared to complex separator design, structural regulation, and interface modification (Fig. 1 ). Designing the gel network and establishing eutectic networks effectively reduces free water activity, thereby inhibiting side reactions. Nonetheless, these approaches are primarily employed to improve the wide temperature range performance of ZABs, with limitations in ionic conductivity and viscosity. Electrolyte additive engineering is a systematic and strategic approach to designing, synthesizing, and optimizing additives to focus on understanding the interactions between additives, electrolytes, and electrodes for improving battery performance. It has been recognized as a promising strategy for electrolyte optimization due to its economic benefits and has become a recent research hotspot with potential for commercial scalability. Wan et al. pioneered the use of Na2SO4 as an additive to ZnSO4 electrolytes, marking a significant advancement in engineering electrolyte additives for ZABs. (Fig. 2 a) [31–38]. A diverse range of additives serves specific purposes, such as extending the stable operating temperature range of the battery [39,40], protecting the electrode/electrolyte interface [41,42], increasing battery energy density [43,44], and providing efficient flame retardant properties to the electrolyte [45]. Addressing the practical demands in the design of electrolyte additives can enhance the performance, longevity, and efficiency of ZABs, thereby making them more viable for these applications. Consequently, it is feasible to tailor electrolyte additives with specialized functions to align with the diverse requirements of different application scenarios and operational environments. Currently, significant research efforts are dedicated to optimizing ZABs through the incorporation of electrolyte additives (Fig. 1), which has been extensively reviewed in depth by many researchers. Specifically, Geng et al. elucidated the different effects of various additives on the anode and cathode to overcome the challenges faced by the electrodes, while Wang et al. reviewed the advantages and role of organic molecular additives [46,47]. However, the existing reviews primarily focus on summarizing types or roles of electrolyte or electrolyte additives, lacking systematic and in-depth discussion of underlying mechanisms [46–51]. Therefore, a comprehensive summary and investigation of the regulatory mechanisms of electrolyte additives is essential to advance electrolyte additive engineering. Such an approach would be invaluable in achieving highly reversible Zn metal anodes and developing high-performance ZABs. In this review, our goal is to provide a comprehensive examination of electrolyte additive engineering by delving into the mechanisms through which different additives affect ZABs. We will start by outlining various challenges faced by Zn metal anodes, including dendrite formation, dead Zn deposition, HER, corrosion, passivation, and other side reactions. Subsequently, we will explore in-depth the specific mechanisms by which different additives influence ZAB performance. These mechanisms include adsorption regulation, pH-buffering control, regulation of redox mediator (RM), and manipulation of water activity. Finally, we will propose detailed guidance for researchers in the field, drawing insights from existing research and encouraging further in-depth investigations. Through these efforts, we aim to make a significant contribution to advancing the field of energy storage. 2 Challenges of Zn anodes Despite the exceptional safety profile, abundant availability, and environmental friendliness of Zn anodes, the emerging ZABs still encounter unavoidable challenges (Fig. 2b), particularly under extreme conditions. This section aims to outline the major challenges and delve into the underlying mechanisms associated with Zn metal anodes arising from their undesirable thermodynamical and kinetic stability. 2.1 Zn dendrite formation Dendrite formation poses a persistent challenge for many metal anodes, including Zn metal anodes. The deposition behavior of Zn directly affects the reversibility of Zn anode. However, due to the uneven nature of Zn deposition, dendrite formation is often inevitable. To inhibit dendrite growth, it is critical to gain a detailed understanding of the formation process [52,53]. The primary cause of dendrite formation is the uneven electric field resulting from the non-uniform deposition of Zn. Initially, Zn2+ is preferentially reduced on the anodic surface and then deposited on favorable nucleation sites (such as crystal planes with low surface energy) after two-dimensional diffusion, resulting in the formation of small tips [54]. These initial tips exacerbate the uneven distribution of the electric field on the anode surface, leading to local variations in overpotential. A higher local overpotential accelerates dendrite growth. Subsequently, newly-deposited Zn2+ accumulates preferentially on the existing crystals with lower surface energy, leading to the continued growth of small tips and eventually the formation of pronounced dendrites, known as the tip effect [55–57]. During the Zn stripping process, dendrites with low adhesion to the substrate tend to detach from the root and become “dead Zn”. The presence of “dead Zn” increases the ineffective surface area of Zn, accelerating corrosion and promoting parasitic reactions. Consequently, the CE is significantly compromised, and the overall lifespan of ZABs is shortened [58,59]. Furthermore, due to its higher hardness compared to other metals (Zn has a Brinell hardness of 412 MPa, significantly higher than metals like Li, Na, and Mg), Zn dendrites are more likely to penetrate the separator. This can lead to potential short circuits within the battery, which is widely recognized as one of the most significant barriers to the practical application of ZABs [60]. 2.2 Side reactions In addition to the dendrite issue, several water activity-induced side reactions in ZABs require attention and deserve considerable focus. These side reactions mainly consist of HER, corrosion, and passivation. These interrelated reactions significantly influence the overall performance and lifespan of the battery. 2.2.1 Hydrogen evolution reaction Zn, as an amphoteric metal, exhibits heightened sensitivity in both acidic and alkaline environments. Consequently, the occurrence of HER is closely tied to the thermodynamic instability of Zn in aqueous media. There exists a competitive relationship between the deposition of Zn2+ and the evolution of hydrogen gas [61]. If this competition is not effectively controlled, it can significantly impact the cycling stability and energy density of the battery [62]. The crux of the matter lies in the standard electrode potential of Zn deposition compared to that of HER. Unlike simple ion plating/stripping, the reaction of Zn under highly alkaline conditions (pH ∼ 14) is more complex, where the intermediate Z n O H 4 2 - acts as a bridge connecting Zn/ZnO (Eqs. (5)–(7). In an alkaline electrolyte, the redox potential of Zn/ZnO (–1.26 V vs. SHE) is more negative than that of HER (–0.83 V vs. SHE, as shown in Eqs. (1) and (2)), indicating that the electrochemical reaction of H2 generation takes precedence. In neutral electrolytes, Zn is oxidized without passing through the intermediate phase. Therefore, the standard reduction potential of Zn/Zn2+ (–0.76 V vs. SHE) is more positive than the HER potential in the neutral medium (–0.83 V vs. SHE), so that, thermodynamically, HER should not pose a threat to the battery. The reaction can be described by Eqs. (2) and (3). (1) Z n O + 2 e - + H 2 O = Z n + 2 O H - - 1.26 V v s . SHE (2) 2 H 2 O + 2 e - = H 2 ↑ + 2 O H - - 0.83 V v s . SHE Under weakly acidic conditions, although HER is still thermodynamically favored (as depicted in Eqs. (3) and (4)), the kinetics of the reaction are much slower due to the more positive HER potential compared with the HER under alkaline conditions. This is one of the main reasons why mildly acidic systems have attracted considerable attention. However, Zn2+ undergoes a solvation/de-solvation process (involving the formation and decomposition of the complex Z n H 2 O 6 2 + ), which results in interfacial polarization [63]. During the de-solvation process, reactive water released from the solvation structure is susceptible to decomposition under the influence of electrons, ultimately leading to interfacial polarization (Fig. 2b). This, in turn, accelerates the onset of HER, resulting in an increase in local pH and the formation of various by-products. (3) Zn 2 + + 2 e - = Z n - 0.76 V v s . SHE (4) 2 H + + 2 e - = H 2 ↑ ( 0 V v s . SHE ) HER degrades battery performance in several ways. Firstly, it continuously generates hydrogen gas, which consumes the aqueous electrolyte and leads to corrosion of the Zn anode, thereby reducing battery capacity. Additionally, the adsorption of evolved hydrogen on the anode surface inhibits Zn nucleation, resulting in increased overpotential and uneven Zn deposition [64]. In addition to compromising the electrochemical performance of ZABs, HER also poses certain safety hazards. This is especially critical for tubular batteries, where the hydrogen produced by HER can increase internal pressure, potentially causing battery expansion or even explosion [65]. 2.2.2 Corrosion and passivation According to the Pourbaix diagram depicting the behavior of Zn in aqueous media, it is evident that Zn is thermodynamically active and undergoes dissolution with concurrent hydrogen evolution across the entire pH range [66]. Therefore, corrosion and passivation processes occur in ZABs in both alkaline and neutral electrolytes, albeit with different underlying mechanisms. These mechanisms can be broadly classified into two categories: self-corrosion and electrochemical corrosion [67]. Self-corrosion predominantly occurs in alkaline electrolytes, and the redox reactions involved in this process can be described as follows. (5) Z n ( s ) + 4 O H - ↔ Z n O H 4 2 - ( a q ) + 2 e - (6) Z n O H 4 2 - ↔ Z n O ( s ) + 2 O H - + H 2 O (7) Z n s + 2 O H - - 2 e - ↔ Z n O s + H 2 O During this process, the intermediate product Z n O H 4 2 - acts as the charge carrier. As the corrosion progresses, Z n O H 4 2 - becomes supersaturated and tends to form ZnO (Eqs. (5) and (6)). Once it reaches its solubility limit in the electrolyte, ZnO precipitates and accumulates on the surface of Zn metal anodes, forming an inert ZnO passivation layer. Therefore, the reaction is thermodynamically spontaneous, and the overall reaction equation for self-corrosion is as follows (Eq. (7)). This passivation layer inhibits further electrochemical reactions and accelerates the depletion of Zn, resulting in a severe loss of capacity battery [68–70]. Typically, ZABs are designed to operate with neutral and weakly acidic electrolytes to minimize the impact of self-corrosion compared to electrochemical corrosion. Electrochemical corrosion refers to the irreversible loss of Zn metal during the battery operation (Eq. (8)). This corrosion is primarily caused by the evolution of H2. When the Zn anode contacts the electrolyte, numerous small protocells form within Zn, leading to H2 evolution and localized changes in the concentration of OH− in the electrolyte, which is manifested as an increase in the local pH. As a result, Zn2+ ions in this vicinity tend to coordinate with OH– and other anions, resulting in the generation of diverse by-products. For example, in the commonly used ZnSO4 electrolyte, the by-product Z n 4 S O 4 ( O H ) 6 · x H 2 O (ZHS) forms through the following reaction (Eq. (9)). These by-products accumulate on the surface of the Zn metal anode, covering active sites and forming a passivation layer that hinders the transport of electrons and ions, as well as the homogeneous deposition of Zn, similar to the role of ZnO in alkaline media [71,72]. (8) Z n + 2 H + ↔ H 2 ↑ + Z n 2 + (9) Z n 2 + + 6 O H - + S O 4 2 - + x H 2 O ↔ Z n 4 S O 4 O H 6 · x H 2 O In contrast to the solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) that provides protection in lithium batteries, the loosely stacked layer of ZHS formed on the surface of the Zn metal anode does not offer protection [73–75]. Instead, it contributes to the continuous corrosion of the Zn metal anode. Additionally, the formation of such by-products not only consumes a significant amount of water, Zn, and solute, which affects the CE of the plating/stripping processes, but also increases the interfacial resistance. These factors collectively reduce the reversibility of the Zn metal anode, often requiring an excess of Zn to counteract these detrimental effects. It is crucial to highlight the intricate interplay among the dendrite formation, HER, and corrosion reactions, which collectively form a complex network of interactions. Essentially, the presence of dendrites significantly increases the contact between Zn metal anode and electrolyte, providing additional active sites for side reactions. The generation of hydrogen gas at the local interface, coupled with an increase in pH, intensifies the formation of by-products. Consequently, the corrosion and passivation processes escalate, leading to an increasingly irregular anode surface that creates favorable conditions for further dendrite growth. These interrelated phenomena create a vicious cycle that undermines battery performance and reduces its lifespan. 3 Electrolyte additive engineering To address the challenges associated with Zn metal anodes, numerous researchers have explored the modulating effects of electrolyte additives in suppressing dendrite growth and side reactions. These additives can be broadly classified into five categories: salts, organic solvents, ionic liquids, acids and macromolecules [76–79]. In this section, we summarize the mechanisms of additive engineering, focusing on four perspectives: adsorption regulation, pH-buffering regulation, RM regulation, and water activity regulation (Fig. 3 ). Adsorption regulation involves additive modulating the zinc anode interface to achieve stable interfacial chemistry. pH-buffering regulation leverages the weak acidity or alkalinity of the additives to dynamically modulate the pH of the electrolyte and at the interface to inhibit side reactions. RM regulation in ZABs usually involves the conversion from inactive Zn (ZHS and “dead Zn”) to active Zn, which facilitates the utilization of Zn. Water activity regulation reconfigures the hydrogen bond network and solvation structure, enhancing tolerance to extreme temperatures and thermodynamic stability. To provide readers a more intuitive understanding of the mechanisms of various additives and the cycling performance of symmetrical cells, we have compiled a comprehensive list of representative research in ZABs in Table 1 . 3.1 Adsorption regulation The unfavorable parasitic side reactions can deteriorate the electrode/electrolyte interface, leading to reduced CE of battery and potential short circuits. In addition, the electrodeposition orientation on different crystal planes has great influence on the morphology of the anode (Fig. 4 a). Adsorption additives typically act on the Zn surface to promote uniform Zn deposition and stabilize the interfacial chemistry. The adsorption mechanism can be specifically categorized into three types, i.e., enhancement of the electrodeposition orientation of the (002) crystal plane, in situ formation of protective layers and electrical mechanisms (Fig. 4b–d). The ideal adsorption additives should possess several key characteristics: (1) High adsorption tendency on the crystal planes prone to dendrite formation, ensuring continuous exposure of the 002 crystal planes and promoting the uniform Zn deposition. (2) The additive molecules adsorbing to the Zn surface should feature hydrophobic groups, facilitating the in situ formation of a protective layer. Additionally, these molecules should competitively adsorb with water molecules on the Zn anode due to their higher zincophilicity, replacing water molecules more effectively. (3) Strong polarity to impede the diffusion and deposition process of Zn2+ through the electrostatic shielding effect. It is also preferable that the additive molecules do not form SEI through chemical reactions, ensuring their enrichment on the anode surface. By possessing these characteristics, the adsorption additive can significantly enhance the performance of ZABs. 3.1.1 Enhanced electrodeposition orientation of the (002) crystal plane The structure of Zn electrodeposition is closely linked to the crystallographic orientation exposed on the Zn surface. As cycling progresses, the (101) and (100) crystal planes, which typically exhibit higher surface energy and are prone to dendrite formation, become increasingly active [120]. Conversely, the (002) planes, characterized by a hexagonal sheet structure and close alignment with the Zn surface, contribute to a smooth morphology and optimal reversibility of the Zn metal anode during deposition along this crystal plane. Therefore, the strong adsorption capacity of the additives to specific planes can be strategically utilized to enhance the spatial site resistance on these planes, effectively exposing the (002) planes. This targeted approach enables the manipulation of Zn deposition orientation during the electrodeposition process, providing a viable pathway for controlling material properties at the microstructural level. The orientation of the crystal planes during electrodeposition is influenced by the deposition rate of Zn2+, with slower rates resulting in larger exposed crystal planes. A homogeneous interfacial morphology promotes stable and reversible plating/stripping of Zn, prompting significant efforts to achieve optimal growth of Zn (002) crystal planes. Zhang et al. utilized 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium cation (BMIm+) as an innovative additive in ZnSO4 electrolyte, effectively promoting the growth of the (002) planes and inhibiting Zn dendrite formation [80]. This effect was attributed to the adsorption of the BMIm+ imidazole ring at the interface, particularly on the (100) and (101) planes, guiding Zn2+ deposition onto the (002) plane, which can be proved by X-ray diffractometer (XRD, Fig. 5 a). As a result, the Zn//Cu asymmetric cell achieved over 4500 stable cycles with a high CE of 99.8% (Fig. 5b). In a parallel study, Huang et al. introduced Zn aspartate (Zn-Asp) additive to promote oriented deposition on the Zn (002) plane [81]. Density functional theory calculations indicated an adsorption energy of 1.03 eV on the (101) plane, demonstrating Zn-Asp's preference for these surfaces. This mechanism played a crucial role in guiding the deposition orientation of Zn2+ and influencing the overall crystallographic texture of the deposited layer. Consequently, the reversibility of the Zn metal anode in ZnSO4-(Zn-Asp) electrolytes was significantly improved compared with ZnSO4 electrolyte, with the Zn//Zn symmetric cell showing stable cycling for over 3200 h at 5 mA cm−2. Similarly, the additive of 3-mercapto-1-propanesulfonate yielded comparable results [82]. This anionic surfactant, characterized by a sulfonic acid group, exhibited a pronounced affinity for Zn. It preferentially adsorbs on other crystal surfaces, facilitating the targeted deposition of Zn2+ onto persistently exposed (002) crystal planes and reducing the energetic barrier associated with Zn2+ deposition. Additionally, studies have demonstrated that β-cyclodextrin can also facilitate the Zn deposition on the (002) crystal plane [83]. These additives promote the exposure of Zn (002) plane through adsorption mechanisms, leading to a uniform Zn plating and inhibiting the side reactions. 3.1.2 Protective adsorption layer stabilizes interfacial chemistry Certain adsorption additives possess the capability to selectively bind to the surface of the Zn metal anode, forming a robust and protective layer. This layer plays a pivotal role in mitigating Zn corrosion. The zincophilicity of these additives contributes to strong and consistent adsorption on the Zn anode surface, while their hydrophobic nature effectively reduces direct interactions between the water molecules and Zn anode. This enhancement improves the anode’s stability and longevity. Some additives can also physically adsorb onto the Zn anode via electrostatic force to construct a robust protective layer without sacrificing the additive molecule itself. This layer helps prevent the undesirable parasitic reactions and degradation of the Zn anode, thereby improving its reversibility and stability. Li et al. introduced dextran, typically used to alleviate ocular inflammation, as an electrolyte additive in an aqueous solution of Zn(CF3SO3)2 to formulate the electrolyte [85]. Dextran's hydroxyl functional groups and glycosidic bonds enhance the ionic conductivity of Zn2+. Additionally, the protective layer formed by dextran hinders direct interaction of free H2O and active water from the solvation structure with the electrode surface, minimizing side reactions. Consequently, a Zn//V2O5 full cell demonstrated stable electrochemical performance. Furthermore, the adsorption of additives can lead to the reconfiguration of the electric double layer (EDL), where water molecules are replaced by the additives outside of the inner Helmholtz plane, inhibiting the HER. One such additive, 2–hydroxy–4′–(2-hydroxyethoxy)–2-methylpropiophenone, achieves this effect [86]. This innovative additive feature two terminal hydroxyl groups primarily for hydrogen bonding, an ether group for optimizing the adsorption conformation, and an exposed, strongly electronegative carbonyl group for efficient interface modulation (Fig. 5c). Together, these groups form a multi-functional and homogeneous adsorption layer at the interface. The resulting EDL with reduced water content enables a high concentration and uniform Zn2+ distribution at the interface, significantly enhancing the thermodynamic stability and electrochemical reversibility of Zn (Fig. 5d). Researchers have reported the use of several electrolyte additives for Zn anodes, including acetylacetone tetraphenylporphyrin, tetraphenylporphyrin tetrasulfonic acid and trisodium methylglycine diacetate [87–89]. These additives have the ability to selectively adsorb onto the Zn anode, forming a protective interfacial barrier that enhances the efficiency of plating/stripping processes. This barrier plays a crucial role in ensuring the high reversibility of the Zn anode, thereby significantly contributing to the overall performance of ZABs. 3.1.3 Uniform electric filed and electrostatic shielding inhibit dendrite growth The growth of dendrites in Zn metal anodes is primarily attributed to the presence of an inhomogeneous electric field and a limited number of nucleation sites. Therefore, the electrical mechanisms play a crucial role in inhibiting dendrite formation. The regulation of Zn2+ deposition mechanisms can be categorized into two main approaches: maintaining a uniform electric field strength or utilizing the electrostatic shielding effect to promote the rapid and uniform diffusion of Zn2+ for the construction of high-performance Zn anode. Enhancing the strength or distribution of the local electric field is an effective means of regulating the internal electric field inside the ZABs. A homogeneous internal electric field can promote the uniform migration of Zn2+ and prevent their aggregation, thereby inhibiting the Zn dendrite formation and improving the cyclic stability and overall lifespan. Fan et al. developed a sustainable Co single atom anchored carbon (denoted as CoSA/C) additive with atomically dispersed Co-N3 sites, which enhances the localized electric field to promote uniform Zn deposition [94]. During the initial plating process, the uneven surface of the Zn anode often leads to the formation of irregular tiny protrusions. The micron-sized sheet morphology of CoSA/C allows it to adjust the adsorption concentration based on the surface curvature of the Zn electrode. CoSA/C preferentially accumulates on the concave surfaces, enhancing the electric field and current density through the charge polarization effect of Co-N3 sites. These sites effectively regulate the charge distribution and reshape the electric field at the electrolyte interface, reducing the nucleation barrier and accelerating the nucleation kinetics (Fig. 5e–g). Additionally, Tao et al. reported the addition of N-decyl-N,N-dimethyl-3-amino-1-propanesulfonate to the electrolyte as an amphoteric surfactant [95]. This surfactant creates a stable adsorption layer at the electrode/electrolyte interface due to its sulfonic acid group. The change in the dipole nature of the additive molecules promotes the formation of a dipole layer at the electrode/electrolyte interface. This layer generates a uniform built-in electric field that regulates Zn2+ transfer and deposition, inhibits the “tip effect”, and significantly reduces dendritic growth, thereby enhancing the electrochemical performance. Electrostatic shielding is another crucial electrical mechanism for preventing dendrite formation. The additive molecules are adsorbed onto the protrusions of the Zn anode surface through electrostatic interactions, creating an electrostatic shielding layer. This configuration effectively shields the protrusions, preventing secondary Zn nucleation on the Zn (100) surface and promoting uniform deposition of Zn2+ [58,98]. NH4 + is a typical ion known for its electrostatic shielding effect. Therefore, the impact of ammonium hydroxide as an electrolyte additive on the deposition behavior of Zn2+ has been investigated [99]. NH4 + repels Zn2+ near the protrusions, inducing the deposition of Zn2+ in the flat region adjacent to the protrusions. This inhibits dendrite growth and leads to a significant change in the morphology of the deposited Zn. Furthermore, Hu et al. pioneered the addition of the rare earth metal CeCl3 to the ZnSO4 electrolyte. In this innovative approach, Ce3+ acts as a competitive ion and forms an adsorption layer on the Zn metal anode [100]. This layer not only creates an electrostatic shielding effect at the electrode/electrolyte interface but also possesses hydrophobic properties that effectively prevent H2O adsorption, thus mitigating side reactions. As a result of this modification, the Zn//Zn symmetric cells exhibit excellent durability and can cycle for more than 2500 h at 2 mA cm−2. Additionally, trivalent cation ions, such as Y3+, have a similar effect [101]. Y3+ exhibits a self-regulated redistribution effect at the electrode/electrolyte interface, forming a sustainable dynamic electrostatic shielding layer. This layer restricts the disordered 2D diffusion of Zn2+ and guides stable 3D diffusion, significantly reducing the nucleation barrier and overpotential. This coordinated process helps ensure the uniformity and flatness of Zn anodes (Fig. 5 h and i). Apart from the adsorption mechanism, the mechanisms of electrolyte additives are also categorized into pH-buffering regulation, RM regulation and water activity regulation. The schematic representation of these mechanisms is shown in Fig. 6 . 3.2 pH-buffering regulation equilibrates interface pH to inhibit side reactions The interface H+ concentration, or pH, is a crucial factor that affects the stability and reversibility of Zn. Inevitable changes in the proton concentration at the electrode/electrolyte interface occur due to the HER. An increase in pH in electrolyte can lead to the formation of ZHS, while a decrease in pH can exacerbate the HER, causing self-discharge and reducing the CE of the system. Moreover, both dendrite growth and side reactions are dynamic processes occurring at the electrode/electrolyte interface, highlighting the importance of maintaining a stable interface pH within an appropriate range to preserve battery performance. To address these challenges effectively, electrolytes must possess the ability to dynamically regulate pH to stabilize the interface pH at all times. Therefore, the urgency of stabilizing pH should never be overlooked, making it crucial to explore electrolyte additives with pH-buffering capabilities. Commonly used pH buffers can be classified into two main categories. The first group consists of weakly acidic ammonium salts that function by dynamically interconverting their weak acid components to effectively regulate pH values. Han et al. utilized low-cost NH4OAc as an electrolyte additive [35]. Using COMSOL simulations, the authors demonstrated that the presence of the interfacial pH buffer OAc− effectively regulated the concentration of precipitated protons, maintaining the interfacial pH at approximately 5.34 compared with the pH value of 7.5 observed in the control group (Fig. 7 a and b). This modification significantly inhibited the formation of inert by-products, thereby improving the cycling stability of Zn anode. Similarly, ammonium dihydrogen phosphate (NHP) has been shown similar effects to NH4OAc [105]. In situ monitoring of pH changes revealed wide pH fluctuations in cells without additives, whereas H2PO4 − and NH4 + in cells with additives actively reacted with excess OH− when the local OH− concentration was high. Additionally, H2PO4 − reacted with excess H+, effectively regulating the interfacial pH. This dual reactivity of H2PO4 − plays a crucial role in maintaining pH balance under dynamic electrochemical conditions. With the assistance of NHP, the Zn deposits exhibited a uniform and smooth dense morphology at various current densities (Fig. 7c–f). Consequently, the Zn//Zn symmetric cell using NHP additive exhibited stable cycling for 930 h at 10 mA cm−2, while the Zn//Cu asymmetric cell demonstrated an average CE of 99.4% over 1000 cycles. The second group of pH buffer consists of nitrogen-containing organic compounds that utilize specific functional groups to adsorb and release H+, thereby achieving pH buffering. Ouyang et al. introduced taurine into ZnSO4 electrolyte and successfully stabilized the interface pH at 4.27 [106]. The sulfonic acid group in taurine inhibits the formation of ZHS by releasing H+ to consume OH− produced during the HER. Additionally, the amino group in taurine helps consume the excess H+, thereby preventing HER under low pH conditions (Fig. 7h). The addition of taurine resulted in a significant decrease in the corrosion current density, indicating a reduced corrosion rate (Fig. 7i). Besides, imidazole, another common type of pH buffer, is a nitrogen-containing heterocyclic organic compound widely used for this purpose. N-Methylimidazole (NMI) is a representative compound in this category [107]. NMI and its protonated form (NMI-H+) form a buffering layer on the surface of the Zn anode. This buffering layer gradually releases protons, eliminating by-products and suppressing disordered 2D diffusion of Zn2+, thereby enhancing anode reversibility. NMI molecules act as ion pumps, transporting protons to the electrode–electrolyte interface, thereby stabilizing the pH. Fig. 7(j) shows the change in pH of the diffusion layer or bulk phase in different electrolytes during the electrodeposition process. This not only improves the reversibility of the Zn anode but also enhances the electrochemical performance of the MnO2-polyaniline (PANI) cathode (Fig. 7k). In the field of ZABs, significant advancements have been made in reducing the pH of the bulk electrolyte to extend battery life [61,108,109]. However, the investigation into stabilizing the pH in the local Zn interface region is still relatively new and requires more comprehensive mechanistic and methodological research. Further studies are needed to delve deeper into understanding the underlying mechanisms and to develop effective strategies for achieving pH stabilization at the Zn interface. 3.3 Redox mediator regulation rejuvenates inactive Zn The use of RMs in electrochemical systems, such as batteries, represents a promising approach to enhance the reversibility and kinetic performance of redox couples. RMs facilitate electron transfer between electrodes and electrolytes without altering the redox products. They offer several benefits, including: (1) Accelerating electrochemical reactions. (2) Lowering the energy barrier to charge transfer. (3) Stabilizing the internal chemistry. (4) Preventing damage from overreaction. Although RMs are commonly used to improve the kinetics of slow interfacial reactions in Li–O2 cells, they also play a crucial role in activating inactive Zn in ZABs [121–124]. In ZABs, RMs are oxidized at the cathode, and then migrate to the anode, where they help to recover ZHS and rejuvenate “dead Zn”. This process significantly improves the cyclic reversibility and the utilization of Zn anode [110,125]. This mechanism highlights the versatility of RMs in improving the efficiency and lifespan of batteries. In ZABs systems, the formation of “dead Zn” is a fundamental cause of capacity degradation. Wang et al. discovered that adding a small amount of KI as an RM to ZnSO4 electrolyte modulates the interface and reduces by-product formation [111]. The I− in KI promotes uniform deposition of Zn2+ by decreasing the de-solvation energy of Z n H 2 O 6 2 + . Additionally, I3 − reacts with “dead Zn” and ZHS, preventing by-product accumulation, and regenerating I− and Zn2+. This additive increases the current exchange density, indicating improved charge transfer. The Zn//Zn symmetric cell with iodide ions achieves a cycle life greater than 3000 h at 1 mA cm−2, 1 mAh cm−2 (Fig. 8 a). The resulting Zn//AC cell showed 81.6% capacity retention with an average CE of nearly 100% CE after 2000 cycles at 4 A g−1 (Fig. 8b). Similarly, Huang et al. addressed this issue by incorporating the 7,8-dihydroxyphenazine-2-sulfonic acid (DHPS) as an RM into the anode electrolyte in Zn-Fe redox flow batteries [36]. During the discharge process, the dissolved DHPS in the electrolyte oxidizes the electrochemically inactive “dead Zn”, then DHPS in transported back to the cathode where it is electrochemically regenerated. This cyclic redox-mediated electrochemical process effectively eliminates the inactive Zn without causing any accumulation, thus minimizing the undesirable reactions. Due to the fast reaction kinetics between DHPS and Zn, the cycle life of Zn-based symmetric flow batteries doubled compared with the control group. In Zn–Fe flow batteries, they cycled for 1500 h with an average CE of 97.5%. While the RM-based additives have made significant progress in ZABs systems, it is important to note that this field is still in its early stages compared to the more mature lithium-based batteries [126–128]. Currently, there are many unexplored mechanisms and strategies within this emerging field, offering researchers numerous avenues for further investigation and exploration. 3.4 Water activity regulation reconstructs hydrogen bond and solvation structure In ZABs systems, Zn2+ primarily exists as Z n H 2 O 6 2 + rather than migrating as individual ions. During the de-solvation of Z n H 2 O 6 2 + , free water molecules become electronically stimulated, leading to a series of side reactions at the electrolyte/electrode interface, which significantly reduces the cell's reversibility. Additionally, concerns arise from the freezing of aqueous electrolytes at low temperatures and the exacerbation of side reactions at high temperatures. Introducing electrolyte additives can alter the chemical environment of the electrolyte by reconstructing the hydrogen bond network and the solvation structure of Zn2+, enhancing thermodynamic stability and inhibiting side reactions accompanying the de-solvation process. This approach also improves tolerance to extreme temperature conditions. Therefore, the ideal additive should possess strong zincophilicity and high polarity, which are crucial for effectively inhibiting water activity and mitigating undesired side reactions at the interface [19,112,129]. Electrolyte additives play a crucial role in inhibiting water reactivity, and their effectiveness is closely related to their electronegativity. In this context, Wan et al. reported the use of the strongly electronegative carboxylate additive sodium tartrate (TA-Na) for this purpose [113]. The tartrate anion interacts strongly with the solvation sheath of Zn2+, effectively weakening the binding between Zn2+ and water molecules. This intervention reduces the presence of water molecules in the solvation structure, thereby mitigating various side reactions (Fig. 8c and d). TA-Na, being a low-cost and non-toxic additive, significantly improves the electrochemical performance of the battery. The stabilizing effect of TA-Na on the water molecules can be attributed to the highly electronegative carbonyl and hydroxyl groups present in the additive. Li et al. revealed that triethylene glycol (TEG) reconfigures the solvation structure, reducing the de-solvation energy barrier, and inhibiting water activity and side reactions [114]. TEG also regulates charge distribution, contributing to the stabilization of Zn anodes. This combined effect results in a Zn//MnO2 full cell with an extended cycle life of over 3000 cycles. In response to the rapid deterioration of battery performance under extreme temperature conditions, the introduction of hydrogen bond acceptors or donor substances into aqueous electrolyte can effectively alleviate such problems. Niu et al. reported a nonionic amphiphilic poly (acrylamide-co-methyl acrylate) copolymer as an additive to Zn(OTf)2 electrolyte [130]. Nuclear magnetic resonance and Fourier infrared spectroscopy combined with molecular dynamics simulations indicate that the introduction of the additive disrupts the initial hydrogen-bonding network of the aqueous electrolyte and reconfigures the solvation structure of Zn2+, which mitigates the water-induced parasitic side reactions. Consequently, operate stably from 50 to –30 °C. Similarly, formamide (FA), a polar organic solvent, disrupts the existing hydrogen bonding network, reconfiguring the occupancy of strong, weak and non-hydrogen bonds, which lowers the freezing point of the electrolyte (Fig. 8e) [115]. The strong coordination interactions between FA and Zn2+ effectively modulate the solvation structure of Zn2+, thereby restraining the active water, corrosion, and dendrite growth on the Zn anode, resulting in an electrolyte with an ultra-low freezing point (Fig. 8f). At –40 °C, the Zn//PANI full cell demonstrated 6000 cycles at 5 A g−1 with a reversible capacity of 80 mAh g−1 (Fig. 8g). 4 Conclusions and perspectives ZABs have emerged as one of the most promising new energy storage technologies due to their low cost, high power density, and environmental sustainability. However, Zn metal anodes still face a series of severe challenges in aqueous systems, including dendrite formation, the presence of “dead Zn” and various types of side reactions. These issues not only coexist but also interact with each other, resulting in performance degradation of ZABs. This article presents a comprehensive review of four key mechanisms of action employed by the electrolyte additives: adsorption regulation, pH-buffering regulation, RM regulation, and water activity regulation. These mechanisms play crucial roles in addressing the challenges associated with Zn metal anodes in ZABs. Despite significant advancements in electrolyte additives and their impact on battery performance, a comprehensive solution to completely resolve the interfacial challenges in ZABs is yet to be achieved. Therefore, there is ample room for further development and research in this field. Future investigations should prioritize the following aspects to drive further breakthroughs (Fig. 9 ). (1) Unveiling the formation mechanism of “dead Zn”. While Zn dendrite fracturing is commonly associated with “dead Zn” formation, the underlying mechanism may be more complex. A comprehensive understanding of the precise causes behind the formation of “dead Zn” is essential for effectively screening functional additives that can efficiently regenerate “dead Zn”, and minimize reduced CE and significant capacity loss. To achieve this objective, in-depth studies are required on the origin and regeneration processes of “dead Zn”, utilizing advanced in situ characterization techniques. These investigations will yield valuable insights and guidance for developing more targeted and effective innovations to mitigate “dead Zn” formation and enhance battery performance. (2) Prioritizing the development of green and non-toxic electrolyte additives. While a wide range of electrolyte additives is available, it is crucial to consider their potential toxicity, which can contradict the environmentally friendly nature of ZABs. Therefore, there is a need to focus on developing electrolyte additives that are environmentally friendly and non-toxic. This approach is essential not only to uphold the sustainability and inherent safety of ZABs but also to align with the broader objective of creating eco-friendly energy storage solutions. By prioritizing the use of green and non-toxic electrolyte additives, ZABs contribute to a cleaner and more sustainable energy future. (3) Developing multi-component electrolyte additives. Current research has primarily focused on using single additives to address challenges faced by Zn anodes, but the impact of a single additive is often limited. While progress has been made in developing multi-functional additives, there is still room for improvement. Therefore, future research should concentrate on exploring multi-component electrolyte additives to enhance the overall performance of ZABs. The ideal strategy would involve combining different components in additives that not only remain inert but also exhibit a synergistic effect. This synergistic effect would result in a combined performance that exceeds the sum of the individual additive effects, creating a “1 + 1 > 2” effect. (4) Improving the wide-temperature performance. The instability of the aqueous solution in ZABs can trigger side reactions, particularly at extreme temperatures. Higher temperatures increase water molecule activity and Zn2+ diffusion, exacerbating side reactions and dendrite growth. Conversely, lower temperatures cause aqueous electrolytes to freeze, severely deteriorating the electrode/electrolyte interface and leading to significant battery performance degradation that cannot meet daily needs. To stabilize water molecules, additives that strongly interact with water, such as highly valent ions and polar molecules, can be introduced. Studying the mechanism of action using advanced characterization tools helps comprehensively explore effective water molecule stabilization across a wide temperature range, thereby enhancing battery performance and safety. (5) Utilizing machine learning for screening electrolyte additives. Traditionally, the development of electrolyte additives has relied heavily on extensive testing and analysis by researchers, which can be time-consuming and labor-intensive. However, the emergence of machine learning has revolutionized scientific research, providing new opportunities for rapidly screening and optimizing electrolyte additives. It is crucial to first determine the descriptors of the additive properties, such as donor number, polarity, permittivity, lowest unoccupied molecular orbital energy level and electronegativity, and then leverage the powerful data processing capabilities of machine learning to design appropriate functional additives based on specific purposes. By employing machine learning algorithms, researchers can analyze large datasets, detect patterns, and make predictions, thereby accelerating the discovery and development of highly practical electrolyte additives. This approach has the potential to significantly enhance the efficiency and effectiveness of electrolyte additive research, leading to the discovery of novel and superior solutions for energy storage applications. (6) Enhancing the utilization and scaling up production of ZABs. Meeting the increasing demand for energy storage requires expanding the production and application of ZABs. Despite significant progress in the laboratory, the low utilization of Zn anodes, and the low energy density of ZABs pose a major challenge for practical implementation. To enhance market competitiveness, efforts must focus on improving the utilization of Zn anodes, reducing production costs, and optimizing manufacturing processes, which can be achieved by introducing inexpensive RM additives. Besides, innovative approaches such as dendrite suppression and interface engineering, along with advanced electrolyte additives, can enhance Zn anode efficiency and cycle life. To address the issue of low energy density, concentrated additives can be used to increase the Zn2+ transference number, or the development of electrode materials and structures with higher capacity and energy density can be pursued. Additionally, cost-effective electrode materials, efficient manufacturing techniques, and streamlined processes are essential for scaling up ZABs production. Collaboration among academia, industry, and government is vital to reducing costs and accelerating the commercialization of ZABs. Recognizing ZABs' potential in the global energy storage market and prioritizing research and development can make them a competitive and sustainable solution, advancing the transition to cleaner and more efficient energy systems. Sci. 16 (2023) 1662–1675. Tao Liu received his bachelor’s degree from Guilin University of Technology in 2023. He is currently a graduate student in the School of Chemical Engineering at Zhengzhou University. His research interest focuses on electrolyte additives of zinc-based aqueous batteries. Ruizheng Zhao received her B.S. degree in Materials Chemistry from Northeast Forestry University in 2015. Then she received her Ph.D. degree in 2020 from Shandong University with Prof. Longwei Yin, majoring in Material Physics and Chemistry. She continued her studies as a postdoctoral fellow in the group of Prof. Dongyuan Zhao at Fudan University from 2021 to 2022. Since 2023, she has been working at Zhengzhou University. Her current research interest mainly focuses on exploring new nanomaterials and understanding their functions in energy storage and conversion devices, including high-energy aqueous batteries, alkali metal-ion batteries and supercapacitors. Zhen Zhou received his B.S. (in Applied Chemistry in 1994) and Ph.D. (in Inorganic Chemistry in 1999) degrees from Nankai University, China. He joined the faculty at Nankai University as a lecturer in 1999. Two years later, he began to work as a postdoctoral fellow in Nagoya University, Japan. In 2005, he returned to Nankai University as an associate professor and was promoted as a full professor in 2011. In 2021, he transitioned to Zhengzhou University, China, where he holds the position of Distinguished Professor and currently serves as the Dean of the School of Chemical Engineering. His research interest is the integration of high-throughput computations, experiments, and machine learning for energy storage and conversion.

coredata.dc:description: Zn-based aqueous batteries (ZABs) are gaining widespread popularity due to their low cost and high safety profile. However, the application of ZABs faces significant challenges, such as dendrite growth and parasitic reactions of metallic Zn anodes. Therefore, achieving high-energy–density ZABs necessitates addressing the fundamental thermodynamics and kinetics of Zn anodes. Various strategies are available to mitigate these challenges, with electrolyte additive engineering emerging as one of the most efficient and promising approaches. Despite considerable research in this field, a comprehensive understanding of the intrinsic mechanisms behind the high performance of electrolyte additives remains limited. This review aims to provide a detailed introduction to functional electrolyte additives and thoroughly explore their underlying mechanisms. Additionally, it discusses potential directions and perspectives in additive engineering for ZABs, offering insights into future development and guidelines for achieving high-performance ZABs.
